a b s t r a c t
This study aimed to investigate the performance of nano-clay modified asphalt mixtures. This study aimed to investigate the performance of nano-clay modified asphalt mixtures. Three different nanoclay materials were selected and each modifier was used with three different concentrations (2%-3.5%- 5%) as substituted for filler. Modified Lottman including hot water conditioning (conditioning 1) and cold water conditioning (conditioning 2) systems were used. Models of water damage were used on half of the identical compacted samples. Cracking, stripping and rutting evaluations were realized with AASHTO T 283 Modified Lottman Test and repeated creep tests (RCT) with Nottingham asphalt tester (NAT). Indirect tensile strength (ITS) tests were realized with control and two types of conditioning systems but RCT were applied with control and Lottman water damage procedure. Nano-clay materials increased rutting resistance of samples with Lottman water damage conditioning method. 2%, 3.5% and 5% nano-clay modified mixtures were found as more rutting resistance than the conventional mixtures according to the AASHTO T283 conditioning. Indirect tensile strength tests were realized with Lottman moisture damage conditioning model. Higher tensile strength values were obtained with 2% and 3% nano-clay modified asphalt mixtures denotes that higher internal friction. Stripping damage of the modified mixtures was interrogated with the ratios of tensile strength concept. In the ratios of tensile strength, 2% each of three nano-clay modified mixtures gives higher ratios. Stripping resistance of the 2% nano-clay mixtures was found as higher than the control conditioned samples based on Modified Lottman Test. It is thought that nano-clay modifiers can be successfully used in view of higher stripping, rutting and cracking resistance with low ratio as 2%. Stripping resistance increased with increasing nano-clay concentrations in view of conditioning 2. As a result of the mechanical test approaches 2% nano-clay content is thought as a suitable ratio in context with stripping, rutting and cracking optimization.

1. Introduction
Rutting and fatigue cracking distresses occur mainly before the service life of pavement. The minimizing of the problems would be more economical for recovery, while reconstructing defects would involve more costs. One of the methods is to modify the properties of asphalt cement for avoiding failure. Various methods, such as the use of different polymers types, were employed. Using additives such as nano-materials to improve asphalt cement and mixture performance has recently become more popular. Nano-composites are among used materials for improving asphalt mixture properties [1–4].
Nano-technology is a highly creative and promising technique for the materials industry. Nano-materials find widespread use in many applications around the world. The Scientific Committee on Emerging and Newly Identified Health Risks defines nanomaterials as a type of material with an outer structure consisting of one or multiple outer dimensions; an internal structure consisting one or more dimensions in the order of 6100 nm; and whose properties differ from those exhibited by comparable materials lacking nano-features. Portland cement with non-materials is being used by many researchers. In recent times, nano-materials have also begun to find use in asphalt pavement mixtures. Nanotechnology is being used to develop new materials, devices and systems by modifying and fashioning them at a molecular level. There are various different types of nano-materials available, with each type offering different opportunities for modifying and improving asphalt mixtures. Examples of nano-materials that can
be used in asphalt applications include nano-tubes, nano-fibres, polymerized powders, nano-sized plastic powders, nanohydrated lime, nano-silica, and nano-clay [5].
Clays can be used for nano-clay production as additive materials. Some are aluminosilicates revealing sheet-like structures. Besides this the layered silicate structures mostly include vermiculite, kaolinite and montmorillonite appertain to the smectite group clays. The thicknesses of layers are generally in the environs of 1 nm. Likewise the aspect ratios are usually in the 100–1500 nm range and hence fairly high. With the bitumen modification, the nano-clay’s discs - or layers - need to be modified and separated through the application of surface treatment. Separating the nanoclay layers greatly enhances the its active surface area, which reaches between 700 and 800 m2/g with this process. With this process a strong and extensive interaction between the asphalt binder and nano-clay develop. Layered silicate can be intercalated or exfoliated in polymer modified bitumen when their scales are nanometric. This polymer chains can intercalate between the clay discs/layers, causing the nano-clay to spread and disperse at a nano-metric level across the polymer matrix. In the conclusions polymer additives enhances mechanical, barrier and thermal characteristics [6].
Nanomaterials such as nanoclay, nano hydrated lime, and nano carbon have significant effects in improving the engineering properties of asphalt binders and mixtures. Many benefits or promising potential of nanoclay materials are concerned with when it was modified with base bitumen for flexible pavement applications. This material has also been used as a secondary modifier to further develop the performance properties of SBS-modified binder [7].
Nano-clay modifications result in considerable improvement in the characteristics of bituminous binders and mixtures; however, further studies need to be conducted before these modifications can be used at larger scales [8]. The main reason for the necessity to conduct further studies before applying these modifications in real settings stems mainly from the limited amount of information on how they actually reduce fatigue and increase rutting resistance in asphalt mixtures. Similar studies have been performed in China on asphalt modified with nano-calcium carbonate (nano-CaCO3) [9,10], which determined that nano-CaCO3 can improve asphalt’s temperature resistance (which is normally rather low) and rutting resistance. The asphalt and nano-CaCO3 mixture results in a system of steady and uniform composition that ameliorates asphalt’s susceptibility to temperature. Despite such observations, there is still limited understanding of the mechanisms through which such nano-modification change the behavior and properties of asphalt.
The effects of layered silicate in asphalt binder were evaluated and a paucity of studies has been made on nano-composite modified asphalt cement and mixture. For example kaolinite clay has been used for improving storage stability issue in polymer modified asphalt. Although kaolinite clay could increase this issue because of its micrometric scale, no other improvements have been observed for physical and mechanical properties [11,12]. Closite_15A and Nano-fill-15 nano-clay materials were evaluated with asphalt binder and mixtures. Nano-clay additives increased the stiffness, indirect tensile strength, resilient modulus, Marshall Stability and improved the rutting resistance of the modified mixtures. But, fatigue strength decreased at low temperatures [13]. Water sensitivity and tensile strength concepts were studied with nano-clay and carbon microfiber modification. Nano-clay agents improved mechanical strength of the asphalt mixtures. 1.5% nano-clay modification showed higher tensile strength and the moisture susceptibility performance [14].
This study aimed to investigate cracking, stripping and rutting resistance of nano-clay modified asphalt mixtures containing different type nano-clay materials and concentrations (2%-3.5%-5%).
2. Materials and methods
Aggregate combination, bituminous binder and three different nano-clay A-B-C materials were used in experimental stages. Stone mastic asphalt gradation was chosen and 19 mm maximum aggregate size was used. Grain size distribution values were presented in Table 1. Granulometry curve was presented in Fig. 1.
Aggregate material is basalt in view of mineralogy-petrography. Basalt aggregate properties were given in Table 2. Basalt aggregates were evaluated and described based on rock petrography and mineralogical tests. Chemical analyses were performed for the main oxides. The mineralogical composition of the basalt was also determined through chemical analyses, and then confirmed with material selection. Table 3 shows the evaluated basalt aggregate’s chemical composition.
AC 50–70 penetration bituminous binder was used. Bitumen properties were illustrated in Table 4 and the cellulose fiber used as a preventive filtration material for SMA design characteristics were given in Table 5.
In addition, nano-clay materials were added to improve the asphalt mixture’s mechanical properties. Three different types of nano-clay were employed. Nano-clay materials were produced from bentonite clays supplied from various regions of Turkey. Used bentonite clays for production of nano-clay A, nano-clay B and nano-clay C were obtained respectively from Eskis ehir-Kütahya, Eskis ehir and Çanakkale regions. Bentonites were dried and grinded nanometric levels. Firstly, bentonites were activated with Na and thus Ca-Bentonites converted to Na-activated bentonites. Naactivated bentonites were purified with centrifuge. It was carried out surface modification with quaternary ammonium salts under the specified reaction conditions. Used organic modifiers were given in Table 6. Also XRF, XRD and SEM methods were performed. Chemical analysis results were given in Table 7 and XRD patterns and SEM images of nano-clays were presented in Figs. 2–7.
Figs. 2 and 4 show that the distance between the layers varies between 34 Å and 37 Å. Nano-clay A showed biggest interlayer distance while nano-clay C has the smallest value. Sieve analysis was done to all nano-clay types and gradation curves showed in Figs. 8– 10. Nano-clay A has the largest surface area. Despite having the highest SiO2 nano-clay C has the smallest surface area (2151 m2/kg).
When the polymer is unable to penetrate between the silicate sheets, a phase-separated composite is constituted, and the properties stay in the same range for traditional micro-composites. In an intercalated structure, where a single extended polymer chain can penetrate between the silicate layers, a well-ordered multilayer morphology results with alternating polymeric and inorganic layers. Silicate layers are completely and uniformly dispersed in a continuous polymer matrix and so an exfoliated or delaminated structure is obtained. Intercalated and exfoliated structures are mostly desirable for improving the material performance [15].
When the polymer penetrates between the adjacent layers of the nanoclay, the gallery spacing is increased and the consisting morphology is an intercalated structure system. An exfoliated morphology occurs when the clay platelets are extensively delaminated and completely separated due to thorough polymer penetration by various dispersion techniques. In combination with nanoclay, couplings agents, such as silane, are used to disperse the nanoclay in a stable manner. Also, silane coupling agents have been
Besides conventional mixtures three different mixture alternatives modified with nano-clay materials were studied. Nano-clays were used as substituted for filler. Filler content was decreased by weight of total dry aggregate at 2%, 3.5%, 5% ratios and nano-clays were added as 2%, 3.5%, and 5% proportions in dry
aggregate mixtures. Marshall Design was performed and design results were illustrated in Table 8. The designs were in accordance with the specifications of the Turkish Board [17].
In the laboratory frame design, one group of conventional and nine groups of nano-clay modified samples were produced. It also worked with conditioned samples as well as unconditioned samples. It underwent two different conditioning systems. Conditioning system 1 was based on Lottman water damage model. In conditioning 1 system, vacuum saturation was firstly applied to specimens at levels ranging from 70% to 80%. The samples were maintained for 30 min at 0.9 bar pressure vacuum cabin. The samples saturated with vacuumwere then maintained for 16 h inside a 18 C computer-controlled freezer, before being immersed for 24 h in a 60 C water bath.
Conditioning system 2 covers cold water conditioning system. Samples were kept in waterlogged canister. The canister was placed in a computer controlled conditioning cabinet. Alternating 12-h periods of +25 C and 25 Cwere sequentially applied for 10 times. In this conditioning system, vacuum saturation was not performed.
The ‘‘Resistance of Compacted Bituminous Mixture to Moisture Induced Damage” (AASHTO T283) is a widely used and effective procedure for forming hot mix asphalt with susceptibility to moisture. This procedure is largely similar to the Lottman test method and brings for a few changes and differences. One of these exceptions is that the samples continue to be saturated with vacuum until the level of water saturation reaches 70–80%-the original Lottman method, on the other side, requires that a set time of 30 min is achieved [18].
The Superpave system used the AASHTO T283 method to determine the level of potential moisture damage. This procedure is mostly similar to the Lottman procedure, save for a few changes and differences. Lately AASHTO T283 has also become a widely employed test procedure to assess the moisture damage performance of asphalt mixtures. However, certain agencies have reported issues regarding the correlation of field observations with laboratory-based results [18].
The repeated load creep test, the indirect tensile strength test, and the Marshall Stability test were performed to compacted
Moisture susceptibility of the compacted specimens was evaluated upon determining Tensile Strength Ratio (TSR) of the samples from the following equation F2/F1 where F2 is the average ITS of the wet specimens and F1 is the average ITS of the dry specimens. A minimum of 0.8 in TSR is required in order to prevent failure [19].
In this research stability and indirect tensile strength ratios were used for evaluating moisture damage. Mixture specific gravities decreased with nano-clay concentrations such as 3.5% and 5% ratios (Fig. 11). Higher and lower specific gravity values can be obtained with 2% nano-clay ratio.
Moisture damage investigation was applied with stability tests and indirect tensile strength tests under the Lottman conditioning (cond.1). Stability and flow properties and damage ratio values were shown in Table 9 and Fig. 12. Modified mixtures with 2% nano-clay concentrations for A-B-C additives gave higher resistance values in context with stripping damage. Based on Marshall damage ratios 2% nano-clay content is preferable ratio in view of stripping. Increasing of nano-clay content from 2% to 3.5–5% density values decreased and damage ratio decreased.
Indirect tensile strength test results were presented in Table 10 and Fig. 13. Tensile strength ratios were obtained with conditioned value and control unconditioned value. In comparison with Marshall Stability ratios indirect tensile strength ratios gave higher
value or else higher stripping resistance for nano-clay modified mixtures at the 2% nano-clay concentrations. In an another research the asphalt mixture specimens’ indirect tensile strength ratios were determined to lower than the Marshall Stability ratios
resembles this situation [19]. In this research indirect tensile strength results were also found lower than the Marshall Stability ratios. Nine mixtures belong to total ten mixtures gave lower damage ratios in context with stripping approach.
Resistance to water damage was alternatively evaluated with another water damage conditioning (cond. 2) model. Table 11 and Fig. 14 give strength values and ratios. In this conditioning model higher ratios were found with increasing of nano-clay concentrations. Because of lower specific gravity values for high nanoclay content mixtures with 2% nano-clay ratio were taken as more harmonious ratio.
The performance of polymer modified asphalt with nano-silica particle additives was evaluated. PMA (PG-76) was mixed with 0%, 2% and 4% of nano-silica relative to asphalt binder weight. Dynamic creep, resilient modulus and moisture susceptibility tests were performed to evaluate the performance of PMA with nanosilica additive under different conditions of moisture susceptibility and aging. The nano-silica particles reduced the water damage
susceptibility, while increasing the asphalt mixtures’ overall strength and resistance. Rutting resistance and fatigue were also improved by the addition of nano-silica particles to the PMA. The aging index indicated that the oxidative aging susceptibility – and especially long-term aging – decreased significantly as a result
of adding nano-silica. Adding nano-silica at a concentration of 4% appears to have resulted in the highest level of improvement for the asphalt binder [5].
Comparative rheological tests for bitumen and mechanical tests for asphalt mixtures with unmodified and nano-clay modified bitumen were also performed. Nano-clay had the effect of improving the asphalt mixtures’ indirect tensile strength, resilient modulus and stability [13].
The performance of the nano-composite modified bitumen was also investigated. The physical, mechanical and rheological properties of conventional bitumen, and bitumen modified with nano-composite have been compared. Nano-composite could improve the physical, rheological behaviors and the stability of the bitumen [20].
The benefits associated with using different levels of SBS and nano-SiO2 powder in mixtures of pavement asphalt were evaluated as well. Different ratios of nano-SiO2 powder and SBS were used to develop five different formulations of bitumen; both unmodified and modified bitumen were then used to prepare the Marshall Samples. Based on the test results, the best performance was observed in asphalt mixtures with 1% nano-SiO2 powder and 5% SBS [21].
Tests were also performed to evaluate the effect of nano-clay addition on asphalt mixtures’ long-term performance. Within the frame of indirect tensile tests, stress levels at 200, 300, 400 and 500 kPa were applied to cylindrical specimens consisting of unmodified and modified bitumen. Test results revealed that adding 1% nano-clay resulted in a noticeable increase in the asphalt mixtures’ fatigue life [22].
Surface science methods were used to investigate the nanoclay-modified asphalt binders’ susceptibility to moisture. Two grades of nano-clay (Cloisite 15A and Cloisite 11B) with different ratios were mixed with the PG 64-22OK binder. SAXD data indicated that adding 4% and 6% (relative to binder weight) of Cloisite 11B, formed exfoliated structures in modified asphalt binders.
Moisture susceptibility results also suggested that, among the different binder and aggregate ratios, 6% Cloisite 11B and 4% Cloisite 15A were the ratios that exhibited the largest adhesive energy [23].
Some characteristics of asphalt binders and asphalt mixtures can be improved with nanoclay modifications but anyway more research is required for applying on a large scale. The major reason for this is that while the nanoclay increased the rutting resistance little is known about how it mitigates the fatigue problem of asphalt. In China, similar research has been conducted on nano calcium carbonate (nano-CaCO3) modified asphalt and illustrated that the nano-CaCO3 can enhance asphalt’s rutting-resistance as well as improve its low-temperature toughness. The mixture of nanoCaCO3 and asphalt forms a uniform-steady system which improves
temperature susceptibility of asphalt at high temperatures. However, the mechanism of asphalt material behavior with this modification is not well understood [16].
It was conducted preliminary tests, blending small percentages of nanoclay-composites into virgin asphalt with aim of producing a binder that is less susceptible to permanent deformation and low-temperature cracking. The study is to significantly reduce the temperature sensitivity of the bituminous binder at service temperatures while sustaining workability at construction temperatures. Nano-modified asphalt may potentially improve the rutting, crack and fatigue resistance of asphalt mixtures [24].
Nanoclay and/or carbon microfiber modified asphalt mixtures were evaluated with indirect tensile strength tests in a modified AASHTO T283 test method. Hot-mixed asphalt samples were damaged in either water or deicing solutions of various concentrations and were then exposed to seven freeze–thaw cycles. The addition of nano-clay and carbon microfiber would improve a mixture’s water susceptibility performance or decrease the moisture damage potential in most cases. As the nanoclay dosage increased the tensile strength of unconditioned asphalt mix samples decreased, but increased for samples conditioned in water. In general, asphalt mixtures modified with 1.5% nano-clay appear to offer high tensile strengths and less susceptibility to water or deicers [14].
Nanoclays can be effectively used as a modifying agent to improve the mechanical properties of asphalt binders. Nanoclays A and B improved the G⁄ and viscosity. Nanoclay B binder hadmore pronounced improvements in G⁄ and viscosity than Nanoclay. According to the direct tension test indicates that Nanoclay A asphalt has better low-temperature cracking resistance than the Nanoclay B asphalt. The blending procedure is crucial in achieving well distributed nanoclay asphalt. The ongoing research will focus on the low-temperature cracking performance and fatigue
resistance of the nanoclay-modified binder as well as the asphalt concrete mixtures made with nanoclay-modified asphalt [16].
4. Rutting evaluation
Repeated creep test was applied with Umatta test apparatus in Nottingham asphalt tester (NAT). Table 12 illustrates interested test parameters used in repeated creep test.
Repeated creep tests were performed to control and nano-clay modified mixtures for Lottman conditioning (cond. 1). Figs. 15–17 illustrate creep curves for A-B-C nano-clay modified asphalt mixtures for control and conditioned mixtures.
Under the modified Lottman water damage model all nano-clay modified mixtures showed higher resistance compared to the conditioned mixtures. Rutting resistance was found higher the control mixtures for modified mixtures. As a general approach such nanoclay concentrations can be leaded higher and lower flow rutting resistance but in each case higher resistance are concerned with control mixtures. Estimating reliable nano-clay content is very important in view of rutting evaluation. Nearly 50% lower permanent deformation can be calculated with selected nano-clay concentrations.
Repeated creep test was also done with unconditioned control and modified mixtures. In the passive condition or else no damage condition as it shown in Figs. 18–20 conflicting results are subjected. Modified mixtures can give lower resistance but in the damage conditions this resistance trend is found as expected. Nano-clay modifiers reveal its efficiency under the water damage mechanisms like in the field condition.

MQ has a more completed effect on the rutting potential than the other variables. This ratio indicates the stiffness of the mixture as well as the minimum flow necessary; it may thus serve to prevent the use of embrittlement-susceptible mixtures. Previous studies indicated that higher MQ levels are associated with higher mixture stiffness and a higher spread/distribution of applied loads. Therefore, higher MQ values provide asphalt pavements the exhibit greater resistance to lasting deformations [25]. However, studies in the literature provide different results and conclusions regarding high MQ levels’ effect on asphalt mixture rutting resistance. [26]. It has been described that in asphalt mixtures consisting of polymer modifiers, MQ levels may not serve as accurate illustration of the level of permanent deformation [27].
Using nanoclay modified asphalt as nano-composites has the effect of increasing aging resistance [28]. It was previously
determined that increasing nano-clay content decreases modified asphalt’s storage stability [29]. Nano-clay modifications improve tend to improve the rheological properties of the binders by decreasing the phase angle (improves elasticity), and by providing higher levels of stiffness in comparison conventional asphalt. These nano-claymodifications can consequently reduce the effect of aging as well [30]. Certain studies have determined that a 2% of nano-clay content in asphalt can increase shear (complex) moduli by up to 184% [16], which illustrates that rutting resistance of the asphalt has been considerably increased by the addition of the nano-clay. These materials are commonly used secondary modifier to increase the performance SBS-modified asphalt even further [31,32].
Adding 2–4% nano-silica relative to the weight of asphalt has the effect of decreasing rutting depth by nearly a half. Moreover, it has been determined that nano-material-modified asphalt mixtures’ rut depths are lower than those of control mixtures, with smaller rutting depths being observed when higher levels of nano-materials are used in the mixtures. However, there are only a limited number of studies on nano-material-modified asphalt mixtures compared to studies on binder modification through the addition of nano-materials [16,33].
80/100 asphalt cement was modified with 1, 2, and 3% chemical warm mix asphalt (WMA) additive and 4% nano-clay respectively. WMA mixture performance was compared with hot-mix asphalt (HMA). Apart from the insignificant low resilient modulus value obtained with the WMA mixtures, the modified WMA mixtures performed incredibly well in the way of moisture susceptibility, rutting, and permanent deformation when compared with conventional HMA. Nanoclay and chemical WMA additive could be effectively used as WMA modifiers. Indirect tensile fatigue test indicated that the number of cycles to cause failure of WMA mixtures were not significantly different when compared with the HMA. However, the number of cycles to cause failure increased significantly for WMA with NCMB B4% when compacted at 135 C [7].
Nano, polymer and nanocomposite modified asphalt mixtures were produced. Tensile strength, resilient modulus and rutting tests were employed for the control and modified mixtures. Nano-clay can enhance physical and rheological properties of the PMA binder mixtures as well as its storage stability. Tensile strength and resilient modulus and also improved rutting resistance over conventional asphalt concrete were obtained [34].
Physical and mechanical properties of bituminous binder could also be improved with modification with nanoclay modification. Stiffness, storage stability, rutting resistance, thermal cracking resistance, and aging resistance properties of the mixtures were also significantly improved. After modification, the asphalt binders were named Nanoclay A modified asphalt binder (NCMB A), Nanoclay B modified asphalt binder (NCMB B), and chemical WMA modified asphalt binder (CWAA). The rheological characteristics of the binders were evaluated with the rotational viscosity, dynamic shear rheometer, and bending beam rheometer tests. NCMB B and CWAA significantly decreased mixing and compaction temperatures. However, only NCMB B showed a significant increase in rutting and fatigue resistance when compared with base bitumen [35].
Rutting, fatigue and moisture damage performance of nanoclay (CL-30B) modified asphalts with newly adopted test methods were evaluated. Incorporating of CL-30B enhances fatigue life of a bituminous binder. It was shown potential of CL-30B to enhance various rheological performance of a binder for better and long lasting pavements [36].
Improvement in fatigue life of asphalt binder with addition of nanoclay evaluated using Superpave fatigue parameter was obtained [37]. Contrary to this observed reduction in fatigue life of binders with addition nanoclay evaluated using Superpave fatigue parameter was found [8,38]. Fatigue life of nanoclay modified asphalt mixture depends on temperature [39]. Improvement in fatigue life of nanoclay modified mixture was observed at 25 C, while reduced fatigue life was found at 5 C compared to control mix [36].
Nanoclay adding to the bitumen improved the resistance to deformation and viscosity of the modified bitumen mixtures. Also using nanoclay have good impact to improve low temperature cracking. Modified bitumen with nanoclay material shows excellent fatigue resistance. Addition of nano-particles to bitumen have effective role for the bitumen used in hot climate area. That means the modified asphalt with nano-clay can resist rutting [40].
5. Conclusions and recommendations
This study investigated the usability of nano-clay materials produced from different sources as modifiers in asphalt mixtures. Three types of nano-clay products were prepared and used at three different ratios of 2%, 3.5%, and 5%. These nano-clay materials were used as substitute of filler material. Different water damage conditioning systems were selected and applied to half of the identical samples. Indirect tension strength tests and repeated creep tests were studied. Marshall Stability values were obtained. AASHTO T 283 moisture cohesion tests were used evaluating efficiency of selected additives. Based on the study results, following statements and conclusions can be drawn:
Nano-clays have been used as modifiers in asphalt mixtures through various different methods. In this study, it was observed that nano-clay materials can be used instead of mineral fillers. Increasing ratios of nano-clay materials in the mixtures led to a decrease in the mixture density. However, a 2% nano-clay ratio was not associated with a significant change in density. Mixtures with nano-clay modification exhibited higher water damage resistance. Nano-clay modification of 2% was found to be effective against water damage. In water damage assessment, nano-clay materials have revealed some more effective results. It is thought that this condition resulted from finer grinding size according to filler gradation. During water damage assessments/tests, indirect tensile strength ratios were found to be smaller than the Marshall Stability ratios. Evaluating moisture damage problem conflicting results can be obtained with different test methods. For this reason moisture damage problem is complex. Because of the lower damage ratios belongs to indirect tension strength test additive ratio contents must be selected with a true approach. It is considered that the grinding size of nano-claymaterials infiller gradation distribution and hence surface area of nano-clays have apositive effect on the performance of asphaltmodification. According to the AASHTO T283 water damage conditioning regime, moisture damaged samples showed a higher rutting resistance increment depending on the ratio and type of nanoclay additive. Nanoclay modified mixtures showed 50% greater rutting resistance than the control mixtures as an average. Although unconditioned samples showed some contradictory results, they generally exhibited an increase in rutting resistance. However, it is believed that conditioning the mixtures according to conditions encountered during actual application and use will better illustrate the effectiveness of nano-clays.
The use of nano-clays in asphalt mixtures is a current topic, with various ongoing studies being conducted on this subject. These studies generally investigate the effects of certain nano-clay materials on asphalt mixtures or asphaltic binders. However, it would be more beneficial if future studies focus on concepts such as the addition method of the nano-clays, the mixing speed, the mixing duration and temperature, and the compaction temperature.

metadata.abstractText: This study aimed to investigate the performance of nano-clay modified asphalt mixtures. This study aimed to investigate the performance of nano-clay modified asphalt mixtures. Three different nanoclay materials were selected and each modifier was used with three different concentrations (2%-3.5%5%) as substituted for filler. Modified Lottman including hot water conditioning (conditioning 1) and cold water conditioning (conditioning 2) systems were used. Models of water damage were used on half of the identical compacted samples. Cracking, stripping and rutting evaluations were realized with AASHTO T 283 Modified Lottman Test and repeated creep tests (RCT) with Nottingham asphalt tester (NAT). Indirect tensile strength (ITS) tests were realized with control and two types of conditioning systems but RCT were applied with control and Lottman water damage procedure. Nano-clay materials increased rutting resistance of samples with Lottman water damage conditioning method. 2%, 3.5% and 5% nano-clay modified mixtures were found as more rutting resistance than the conventional mixtures according to the AASHTO T283 conditioning. Indirect tensile strength tests were realized with Lottman moisture damage conditioning model. Higher tensile strength values were obtained with 2% and 3% nano-clay modified asphalt mixtures denotes that higher internal friction. Stripping damage of the modified mixtures was interrogated with the ratios of tensile strength concept. In the ratios of tensile strength, 2% each of three nano-clay modified mixtures gives higher ratios. Stripping resistance of the 2% nano-clay mixtures was found as higher than the control conditioned samples based on Modified Lottman Test. It is thought that nano-clay modifiers can be successfully used in view of higher stripping, rutting and cracking resistance with low ratio as 2%. Stripping resistance increased with increasing nano-clay concentrations in view of conditioning 2. As a result of the mechanical test approaches 2% nano-clay content is thought as a suitable ratio in context with stripping, rutting and cracking optimization. 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
